snippet.title: Coast council revealed as top dog for registration fees
snippet.content: SUNSHINE Coast dog owners are coming out on top. News Corp analysis has compared the Sunshine Coast's pet registration fees with nine other councils across the southern Queensland coast, showing just how little we fork out for our furry friends when compared with our neighbours. Annually, the Fraser Coast Regional Council charges the general public $57 to register a dog and $52 for concessions. Although a discount of $20 applies to those who pay early, Sunshine Coast council and Gympie council offer further discounts and incentives for responsible animal owners. In Gympie, residents can register a microchipped and desexed dog for free, while registering a desexed dog was $25. The Sunshine Coast Council charges a meagre $13 to register a desexed and microchipped dog. Noosa council charges $38.50, and both councils waive fees completely for pensioners. In Rockhampton a desexed and microchipped dog can be registered for $17 or $8.50 for concessions, while the Livingstone Shire Council and Gladstone Regional Council also offer considerable discounts for responsible pet owners. Other councils also had similar fees for a third dog, with Gympie Regional Council charging $266 for an application. The North Burnett Regional Council charged a fee of $208 and Bundaberg Regional Council charged $217 for an application fee for a third dog. On the Sunshine Coast having more than two pooches on your property will cost you slightly less than neighbouring regions. To apply to register an extra dog, Sunshine Coast council charge a non-refundable fee of $194 before they will consider your application. Noosa charges a non-refundable fee of $130.50.
